headline.main: Studies Confirm Relationship Of Alcohol to Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Analysis of six long-term studies involving over 300,000 women confirms drinking alcohol can raise woman's risk of developing breast cancer; finds very small rise in risk for those who consume no more than one drink a day, with risk increasing with amount of alcohol regularly consumed; finds women who consume two to five drinks a day are 41 percent more likely to develop breast cancer than nondrinkers; Dr Stephanie Smith-Warner, lead author of study, comments, interview; study is being published in Journal of American Medical Association (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: An analysis of six long-term studies conducted among a total of more than 300,000 women has confirmed that drinking alcohol can raise a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. But the increase in risk is very small for those who consume no more than one drink a day. The findings, being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association, showed that a woman's risk of breast cancer rose with the amount of alcohol she regularly consumed, strongly suggesting that by drinking moderately or not at all a woman could reduce her chances of getting breast cancer.
